headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; By Telegraph to the New-York Daily Times. TWO WEEKS LATER FROM CALIFORNIA. ARRIVAL OF THE FALCON AT NEW-ORLEANS. Upwards of $2,000,000 en route for New-York on the Ohio, &c., &c., &c. General Scott and the Southern Rights Party The Dilliculty Between Messrs. Polk and Cullom-Correction. Free Soil Rnatilication Meeting at Boston. City Conventions in Philadelphia--Sudden Death. Democratic State Conventiota. Interesting Iteins from the South--The Georgia Union Party. Arrival of the City of Manchester. Failure of the Southern Mail. Escape of Seven Slaves--Fatal Accident. Murder in North Carolina. Capture or Runaway Slaves. Navigation of the Ohio. Cholera at Rochester.

docs.lead_paragraph: The steamship Falcon has arrived at this port with San Francisco dates to Aug. 1. The Oregon had arrived at Panama from San Francisco, bringing down $2,000,000 of gold dust on freight. Sickness has abated on the Isthmus. The steamship Ohio left Aspinwall for New-York on the 19th inst., having on freight upwards of $2,000,000 gold dust. Capt. SNOW, of the U. S. Navy, Is among the passengers.

headline.main: GREAT BRITAIN.; POLITICAL AND GENERAL NEWS. The Fishery Dispute--The Queen's Visit to Belgium--Lawyers in Parliament--Preserved Fruits--Literary Intelligence--Pamphlet by Charles Mrthews, &c. [BY THE STEAMER ASIA.]

docs.lead_paragraph: By tar the most prominent and interesting topic of discussion, during the past week, has been the unfortunate " fishery question," now in agitation between the British and American Governments. A goodly amount of editorial," leaders" have already appeared; but the subject has been not less warmly argued in private circles, and, in fact, in every place where men most do congregate.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

headline.main: AMERICAN SLAVERY.; Condition and Character of the English Laboring Classes, General Suggestions on Reform. LETTER FROM A DISTINGUISHED ENGLISH AUTHOR TO AN AMERICAN FRIEND.

docs.lead_paragraph: MY DEAR SIR: I have to offer you my thanks for sending me a very remarkable book, Uncle Tom's Cabin, which followed on the receipt of your letter of the 25th April last. The book horrifies and haunts me ; and I cannot help writing to you somewhat at large upon it.
docs.abstract: American Slavery treated by an Englishman

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; THE DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY MEETINGS.--ADDITIONAL PARTICULARS. SIXTEENTH WARD. SWINDLE UPON WESTERN TRAVELERS. CHARGE OF ARSON. PAINFUL ACCIDENTS. IMPORTANT TO LAWYERS AND LITIGANTS. HARLEM RAILROAD. ROBBERY AT THE HOUSE OF REFUGE. SUICIDE. SUPERIOR COURT. COMMON PLEAS.

docs.lead_paragraph: DITIONAL PARTICULARS.--Since the Primry meetings of the Democracy on Thursday night, we have obtained additional accounts of the disgraceful proceedings. The polls of the " Bloody Fourth," as noticed in the Times yesterday, were the scene of riot and disorder never before equaled in the "Bloody Sixth." After the election,

headline.main: GERMANY.; German Watering Places--Habits of the People-Ischi--Historical Traditions, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: Smoking, beer-drinking, erudition and good nature--such is, with foreigners, the vulgar category of German national characteristics. A passion for going to watering places should be added to help out its completeness. The number of those who indulge it annually, may be reckoned at over one bundred thousand. Dr. HUFELAND,

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: There is now going the rounds of the papers, a brief article from the Boston Medical and Surgical Journal, defending the use of fruits, in their season. The Doctors have well-timed their defence, for there are those in the Cities who taboo every kind of fruit to their families so long as the Health Officers report a case of Cholera east of Cincinnati.

headline.main: NEW-ORLEANS.; Siesta of the Season's Amusements at Pass Christian--Anniversary Ceremonies-Politics--Capt. Marcy's Fate--The Crops, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the time of year when all nature seems to rest, as if tired of its own exertions. The products of soil have all matured. The earth has labored and brought forth a bountiful harvest, and the barns and the granaries shall be filled there with.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The following letter was written by Mr. WEBSTER to a friend, some years ago. It will be read with interest, not only for its intrinsic beauties, but as a purely literary production from this eminent statesman:

docs.lead_paragraph: SUDDEN DEATH.--A man apparently about 50 years of age was discovered dead, sitting in a chair on the stoop of the Atlantic Hotel, Hoboken, at 6 o'clock on Wednesday evening.
docs.snippet: SUDDEN DEATH.--A man apparently about 50 years of age was discovered dead, sitting in a chair on the stoop of the Atlantic Hotel, Hoboken, at 6 o'clock on Wednesday evening.
